Most people here have no clue who you are. 


Do you want to know why?

I don't care if you do, it's rhetorical and you know I am going to tell you anyway.

We are all free to speak our minds here!

-> It's because you're too busy creating content about the agenda
you want to push.

It's what most people here do.

Do you believe that people show up and engage with your content because you're popular and liked?

Everyone here has an agenda, and they'll do anything to accomplish
their selfish goals . .

-> Unless you disarm them and give them a reason to do something
else entirely different.

You actually have the freedom to be yourself and not what the algorithm wants you to be.

People want to connect with people

-> not with their agendas or their A.I.

There's too much curated, manicured and manufactured content here.

-> It's just not how people think or interact.

If you're just chasing the algorithm, then you're not here for you or your community.

And you're not free.

There needs to be more vulnerability and truth

-> so that people can see your life is as imperfect as theirs is.

That's when people will connect and resonate with you as themselves.

Do you know why I believe people started using AI commenting
in the first place?

-> Because the posts have become so drab, similar and boring.

People just can't bring themselves to keep reading and commenting on them.

Freedom is a hell of a lot better than popularity.

Try it out and let me know how you feel.

Yours truthfully,

10 Phrases That Kill Work Conversations:
(and what to say instead)

Valuable post fromon strengthening connections.

We've all been there.

That moment when a conversation hits a wall.
One phrase can shut everything down.

Here are the biggest conversation killers,
and what to say instead:

"Yeah, but..." 
"Good point. What if we also..." 

"You should have..." 
"Moving forward, let's..." 

"I already told you..." 
"Let me clarify my thinking here..." 

"You're wrong" 
"Walk me through your thinking on this." 

"We've always done it this way" 
"How would you improve this?" 

"I don't have time for this" 
"This is important. Let's find time for it." 

"Just figure it out" 
"What challenges are you running into?" 

"That's not my problem" 
"What's blocking you?" 

"You're being too sensitive" 
"Help me understand why this matters to you." 

"That's not how it works" 
"Let me share what I know about this..." 

Here's what matters:

One stops the conversation.
The other moves it forward.

Next time youâ€™re about to use a conversation killer,

Pause.

Choose words that welcome input instead of blocking it.

What phrase has helped you build better conversations?

 Repost to help build better conversations

postsData.content:
Worst compensation plan ever or systemic theft? You tell me.

Here is another submission for one of the worst compensation plans ever. This one by one of the big 3 cell phone providers in the states.

You have a monthly quota. You donâ€™t get paid any commission if you are not over 40% of quota for the month. Zero. Nada. If you hit 40% or more, you get paid on the 40% retroactively.

However, if you donâ€™t hit your full quota for the quarter, the shortfall gets carried forward as a negative balance to be offset by earned commissions the following quarter. They make you pay them for not hitting their inflated unachievable target.

They take your earned compensation from you the following quarter for not hitting their targets the prior quarter. It's just unreal. You were never paid compensation on the missed target but are having compensation taken away for missing it. It just insane.

As you can imagine, there are salespeople that have not been paid commission in 6 or 9 months but have had hundreds of thousands of dollars in sales.

This is a Fortune 500 multi billion dollar publicly traded company doing this to reps without big six figure base salaries. Most of these folks are 20-somethings with very little experience or knowledge of what is allowed or not.

I canâ€™t imagine how this could possibly be legal. I know it is not moral or ethical or fair or reasonable. It appears to be systemic theft by the employer on unknowing employees.

I suggested that she reach out to the attorney generalâ€™s office, the department of labor, escalate to the c-suite, and document everything.

As far as a lawyer goes, unless they make it a class action, there isnâ€™t one that is going to go after a multi-billion-dollar company over tens of thousands of dollars in stolen commissions.

Just gross. You canâ€™t have compensation taken away for compensation you never earned. Just so wrong.

postsData.content:
When I was a VP of Sales (2x), the worst AE was closing 40-45% of their demos.

The best AEs were closing 60-75% of their demos.

Here's what they didn't ask during their demos:

â†’ "any questions?"
â†’ "does that make sense?"

Because hereâ€™s what happens:

You run a great demo.

The prospect nods along. No objections. No pushback.

And thenâ€¦ they disappear. Or worseâ€”pick someone else.

So I taught them hunt for objections.

Here are 4 questions they consistently asked on calls (that you can steal):

1. "What about [feature] do you feel isn't going to work for you?"

2. "If you were to show this to your team, where do you think they'd push back?"

3. "On a scale of 1-10, 10 being this is EXACTLY what I want and 1 being not at all, what would you rate this feature in terms of [solving problem?"

4. "What hesitations would [stakeholder] have about us?"


Takeaway:

Weak discovery creates strong objections later.

Strong discovery surfaces them earlyâ€”when you still have a chance to handle them.

If you donâ€™t, the first time you hear "No" is when the deal is already lost.


Which of these 4 questions would have saved your last lost deal?

I used to think that people would respect you if you dressed well, had a lot of money, looked great, or had some special talent. 

But over time, I realized that these things are not enough.

If you disrespect others, make people feel inferior, or create a negative environment where those around you feel bad about themselves, no one will truly respect you.

What really matters is being kind, respectful, and empathetic.

If you want people to like your vibe and enjoy being around you, here are 3 things you should do when meeting someone:

Listen actively â€“ Give the other person your full attention instead of just waiting for your turn to speak.


 Show respect â€“ Treat everyone with kindness, no matter who they are.


 Make them feel valued â€“ A simple compliment or genuine appreciation can make a big difference.

When you focus on making others feel good, respect naturally follows.



Do you agree?

Your progress isnâ€™t a straight line (and it shouldnâ€™t be).

If you feel like youâ€™re going in circles, youâ€™re not stuck. Youâ€™re just moving up the spiral.

But sometimes itâ€™s hard to see the progress.

Hereâ€™s what you can do when the journey feels unclear:

1. Appreciate unseen efforts

Not every milestone is visible. Working on your mindset, building relationships, and gaining emotional resilience arenâ€™t things you can measure on a scoreboard - but they matter just as much.

2. Reframe setbacks as opportunities

Itâ€™s easy to feel like youâ€™re running in circles when things go off track. But every loop gives you a chance to apply what youâ€™ve learned and try again with new insights.

3. Celebrate small wins

Even when things seem repetitive, take a moment to recognize how far youâ€™ve come. Small wins and daily actions compound into big results over time.

4. Trust your unique path

Your spiral wonâ€™t look like anyone elseâ€™s. Some loops might feel long, others short. The only comparison worth making is with your past self.

5. Stay patient through the process

Growth isnâ€™t instant. Keep showing up, keep putting in the effort, and keep trusting that each loop is bringing you closer to your goals.

Progress isnâ€™t about how it looks to others.

So, if you feel like youâ€™re running in circles, donâ€™t stress.

Youâ€™re not back at square one - youâ€™re leveling up with every turn.

When your founders ask if you want to come meet up for a weekend?

How would you respond? Me: HECK YEAH!!!!

It was an action packed weekend

Most conversations were about how to make things better

How we can make our customers happier

How we can provide a better service

Very important conversations IMO!!!

But getting to get around the team

Priceless!

Face to face convos
Breaking bread together
Creating memories together
Hiking the "wilds" of San Fran
Almost winning at Catan for the 1st time

All these help strengthen our bonds, build friendships, truly get to know one another. These are the moments that make all the typical "startup" struggles worth it. IMO, its the relationships that make or break a company, whether its the team, our customers, or suppliers, you name it. They are all extremely important.

So, if you could meet up with your team...

Where would you go? What would you do?

PS: I will beat the team at Catan at some point, its inevitable. I mean everything is possible, right? Even if its a .000000000000001% chance

It may also be worth mentioning that life satisfaction and fleeting happiness are two different things. People with kids report lower moment to moment happiness than people without kids, but report higher life satisfaction overall (long term).

postsData.content:
Baby pikas, called pups, are small, fluffy mammals that live in rocky, mountainous regions. Well-camouflaged with their brownish-gray fur, they are expertly suited to their alpine homes.

What's fascinating is that baby pikas remain in underground burrows for the first couple of weeks after birth. This way, they stay protected from predators and the extreme weather conditions in their harsh habitats.

During this secluded period, their vulnerable bodies begin to grow stronger, preparing them for the challenges of mountain life. After about two to four weeks, they venture out, joining their parents on foraging trips. This gradual exposure is crucial, as it allows them to learn essential survival skills from their parents while gradually adapting to the outside world.

While adult pikas are known for their sharp, high-pitched â€œeep!â€ calls used for communication and warning of danger, pups produce softer squeaks. These sounds help them stay connected to their mothers and siblings, ensuring their safety in the wild.

Though tiny, their vocalizations are an essential part of their survival.

Water is an important resource for them as they maintain their burrows, and survive in their mountain habitats. Future generations of baby pikas depend on the access to ample and clean water to thrive.

If we invest in clean water supply systems, protect watersheds, and educate communities about water conservation, we can ensure a sustainable water future for all species.

Animals will thrive and flourish alongside us as stewards of the environment.

comments.commentText: SÃ¶ren, your commitment to sustainability and clean water access shines through beautifully in this post. Linking the story of baby pikas to the critical need for clean water reminds us how interconnected our efforts and the environment truly are. Keep inspiring us with your impactful mission!

If you're not fully content with where you are in life, remember: you have the power to make choices that shape the person youâ€™re becoming. 

Itâ€™s not always easy, but itâ€™s always possible. Yes, there will be challenges and tough moments, but if you stay determined, youâ€™ll find the strength to keep moving forward.

Hereâ€™s how:

 Know Yourself: Take the time to discover your values, strengths, weaknesses, passions and dreams. The more you understand yourself, the clearer your path becomes. With this knowledge, you can focus on what matters and let go of distractions.

 Create Your Roadmap: While many chase external goals like money or success, what we're truly seeking is identity. Once you define who you want to be, set specific, measurable and achievable goals. Let inspiration, not obligation, drive your actions. Own your journey, take responsibility and move forward with purpose.

â€ï¸ Take Action: Life may feel short, but every step you take matters. Progress is made with consistent action, even if it's just a small step each day. Aim to be a better version of yourself today than you were yesterday. Small steps lead to big change.

â³ Stay Committed: Transformation doesnâ€™t happen overnight. It requires patience, resilience, and a willingness to keep going, even when it feels tough. As Naval Ravikant wisely said, "Grind and sweat, toil and bleed, face the abyss. It's all part of becoming an overnight success."

We are all on this path and I believe each of our futures are full of possibility and greatness.

Every time I came home from my 9-to-5 job, there was one question on my mind: Whatâ€™s next?

I wanted to create something of my own, but like most entrepreneurs, my journey didnâ€™t start with instant success.

As a Marwadi, I grew up seeing how significant weddings are. While India was going digital, I saw an opportunity: personalized wedding websites.

To help the business grow, I taught myself SEO. I wanted better visibility, better clients, and, most importantly, a steady income.

These one-page websites, with photos, music, and personal messages, became our niche. While it wasnâ€™t a fortune (we earned â‚¹20-30k), it was enough to show me the potential of entrepreneurship.

It also taught me the importance of finding small wins and turning them into opportunities.

Eventually, I had to make the tough decision to shut the company down. It wasnâ€™t easy, but it cemented one thing for me: I was meant to be an entrepreneur.

Here are the lessons that the first venture taught me:

1. Every setback is a setup for success: Failure is just part of the process. Itâ€™s where real growth happens.

2. The power of a side hustle: My side hustle often outperformed my monthly salary. That extra effort is what fuels breakthroughs.

3. Keep learning: I didnâ€™t know SEO, but I learned it because the business needed it. Skills compound over time.

That first company didnâ€™t succeed, but it taught me everything I needed to know.

Resilience, risk-taking, and finding unconventional opportunities.

Today, as I look back, I know that shutting down that venture was the first step toward building something bigger.

Itâ€™s a reminder that the road to success isnâ€™t linear.

What did your first venture teach you? Let me know in the comments.

Joe Glick
postsData.content:
BIOMIMICRY CONTINUUM â€“ Part 5 â€“ CURATING Agentic Expertise
Multidisciplinary expertise is critical to correctly define the key premises driving problem analysis and solution architecture, and the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem (left image) enables capturing that expertise as a reusable computing asset.

The current AI chaos is due to 70 years of narrow and unexamined premises. The promise of AGI in the 1950s was rooted in premises that have been disproven by real-world evidence but blindly adhered to by those making todayâ€™s AGI claims. Key examples:

-Premise: language is the source of intelligence
-Reality: intelligence is the source of language - babies are intelligent before they can speak

-Premise: data is a representation of the real world
-Reality: data is the output of a machine and represents only what the machine was designed to capture

-Premise: the brain constructs objects by identifying frequent patterns of object bits
-Reality: the brain contains networks of abstract concept cells which fire when the concepts are presented in diverse versions and formats (text, image, sound, etc.)

-Premise: neural networks imitate how the brain reasons by processing massive data exhaustively
-Reality: the brain computes the relevance of inputs using inhibition networks, filtering out over 99.99% of sensory data

There are more, but the point is that the main objectives of curation are:
1-Ensure that knowledge from all relevant domains is included in the ontology
2-Map the relevant knowledge concepts across the domains to problem and solution concepts
3-Maintain the landscape concepts (science, business, regulation, etc.) reasonably updated

To enable these objectives, the custodian systems must support:
1-Biomimetic digital twinning of problem and solution concepts
2-Independent update by authorized experts
2-Simulation and testing of the impact of proposed updates across the ontology architecture

The methodology and technology to build this type of biomimetic digital twin ecosystem exist, we have produced published results, and I have discussed this in my posts.

The vision of the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem in the image, however, is in early stages and will require committed partners with the necessary resources who want to participate in shaping the implementation of this new paradigm.

Mental Health in Corporate: Because Burnout Wasnâ€™t in the Job Description

Letâ€™s be real, corporate life can feel like a never-ending episode of â€œSurvivor,â€ where office politics, deadlines, and â€œurgentâ€ emails at 11 PM are the obstacles standing between you and a peaceful state of mind.

But hereâ€™s the thing: Hustle culture shouldnâ€™t come at the cost of your mental health. If youâ€™re constantly running on caffeine, stress, and â€œjust one more task,â€ youâ€™re not being productiveâ€”youâ€™re being exploited (sometimes by your own habits).

So, how do you stay sane in a game where everyoneâ€™s playing 4D chess?

1. Take Refresh Breaks Like a Boss â€“ No, doomscrolling emails doesnâ€™t count. Step away, take a walk, stretch, breathe. Your brain needs space to function.

2. Know When to Exit the Chat â€“ Not every debate or office drama needs your energy. Silence is a power move.

3. Set Boundaries and Mean It â€“ If youâ€™re always available, people will expect you to be. Respect your own time first.

4. Find Your â€˜Non-Workâ€™ People at Work â€“ A quick rant, a shared meme, or a coffee break with someone who gets it can be the ultimate reset.

5. Detach Your Worth from Your Work â€“ Youâ€™re not just your KPIs. Youâ€™re a person first, an employee second.

Mental health isnâ€™t a luxuryâ€”itâ€™s fuel for sustainable success. Take care of it like you would your paycheck. After all, no promotion is worth losing yourself.

During our session, as we ventured beyond the visible realm of leadership tactics, her unconscious mind directed us to something unexpected: her inner Trickster.

"I don't do sneaky," she insisted, her voice carrying the weight of years of structured leadership. "I lead with integrity."

And she does. But integrity can have a good time, too.

This is where transformation begins. She needed to rethink how she understood the Trickster. Trickster energy is about deception, but only in its Shadow. In the light it's about joyous disruption. It's the art of turning walls into doors, transforming rigid patterns into playful possibilities.

Once she saw that, she was brave enough to create a relationship with her inner Trickster. It told her that Instead of pushing harder, she can change the pattern. She learned to meet resistance with curiosity instead of frustration. And it showed her when and how to use humor and a light touch where before sheâ€™d used authority.

The results were amazing to both of us. A months long battle dissolved in days.

Sometimes the most powerful change doesn't come from pushing harder, it comes from changing the game entirely. Like turning lead into gold, it's about seeing the potential in what we've been resisting.

If youâ€™re trying to find a work-life balance...

And trying to build a successful business read this:

1. You will never have a 50/50 split.
2. You will work more than you rest.
3. You will miss important moments.

The idea of perfect balance is a myth.
You need to adjust your expectations ASAP:

- One day, your family might need you more than work.
- One day your business might need you more.
- One day you might need yourself more.

You've got to prioritise what's important in the moment.

Learning to recognise when you need each moment is how you make progress. Building a business requires sacrifice and a lot of it. It's what you signed up for.

But itâ€™s up to you to manage those sacrifices, make conscious decisions, and accept that you wonâ€™t always get it right because balance doesn't exist.

This is the reality of startup life.
